title: Bruce speech on election violence - support claim

content.description:
“The conduct of the late election [of 1876] in Mississippi...put in question and jeopardy the sacred rights of the citizens; and the [congressional] investigation contemplated...has for its objective...the protection in all their purity and significance of the political rights of the people and the free institutions of the country.... 
The evidence in hand and accessible will show...that in many parts of the State corrupt and violent influences were brought to bear upon the registrars of voters, thus materially affecting the character of the voting or poll lists.... Threats and violence were practiced directly upon the masses of voters in such measures and strength as to produce grave apprehensions for their personal safety, and as to deter them from the exercise of their political franchises.... 
The sober American judgment must [prevail] in the South as elsewhere in the Republic, ...that differences of religion, nationality, or race can neither with safety nor propriety be permitted for a moment to enter into the [political] party contests of the day.”
Source: Speech by Blanche K. Bruce, United States senator from Mississippi, the first African American to serve a full term in the Senate, 1876
content.question: Blanche K. Bruce’s speech could best be used as evidence to support which of the following claims?

choices.label: De jure segregation laws prevented African American politicians from attending sessions of their legislatures.
African American men who enlisted in the Union Army often promoted political equality.
African American political leaders demanded their Constitutional rights during Reconstruction.
Racial violence was ineffective in restricting the participation of African Americans in politics.

content.answer: African American political leaders demanded their Constitutional rights during Reconstruction.
